Grey Nuns of the Cross, Odanak, P.Q.
April, 7th, 1939.

M. B. Maurault, M.D. Agent,
Pierreville, P.Q.

Dear Sir:

Referring to the request concerning our refrigerator. It is now a year we cannot make use of it.

Men of experience have come to see what could be done to it and it has been found that it would cost not less than one hundred dollars ($100.) and even more to repair it and yet without any guarantee.

A request for a new one has been made to the Department by our General Bursar in Ottawa. The Department has promised to inform you about the matter, but we have had no news yet.

You would greatly oblige us if you would be so kind as to renew the request for same.

Yours much obliged,

[Signature]
Superior.
Poville,
April 732.

Dear Sir,

Please find attached a letter received from Mr. Macdonald concerning the resignation of Mr. Smith's heading which has been out of commission for at least a year now. Ripe is now almost impossible as this mark of refrigerator has been out of the market for quite a few years so it is impossible to find any more. Owing to these complications I think it would be more practical to buy a new machine and to forget.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6104, file 328-5, part 6)
Ottawa,
April 13, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the request that you have received for an electric refrigerator for the residence at the St. Francis R.C. school.

I feel that all parties concerned will readily understand that if an electric refrigerator were supplied at one Indian day school similar requests would be received from many other schools. This would involve an expenditure for which no funds have been provided.

Have you considered the possibility of purchasing an ordinary icebox at a cost not exceeding $20.00 to $25.00? The Department would be prepared to allow this on the understanding that the Rev. Sister would pay for the ice that would be required.

With regard to your letter of the 10th instant the Department will allow an amount of $4.00 for removing the storm windows and replacing them with the screen windows.

Yours truly,

Dr. B. Maurault,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, Que.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant with reference to the wages of the furnace man at the St. Francis R.C. School.

There appears to be a growing tendency on your part to allow expenditures at this school to increase. You should be fully aware of present conditions and the difficulty that the Department is experiencing in obtaining the necessary funds for the operation of schools. It is difficult to understand why it was necessary to employ a man from September 20. However, as you have committed the Department to this expenditure you may resubmit the voucher for his wages from that date.

I wish to point out that your letter requesting authority to employ the furnace man was dated October 27 and consequently the man had been working for over a month before you applied for the necessary authority. In future unless you apply for authority before incurring expenditures the Department will be unable to consider their payment and you will be personally responsible.

We allow $40.00 a year for a janitor at this school. In spite of that fact you have been submitting accounts for various other services which should be performed by the janitor. Already we have expended an amount of $65.00 for removing screens and storm windows, cleaning class rooms and housecleaning. It should be definitely understood by all parties concerned that we do not intend to expend any more money for these services during the current academic year. This work will have to be done by the janitor for the amount which he is paid.

Dr. B. Maurault,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, Que.
It should be understood also that the furnace man's salary will not be paid after May 1, 1941, and if possible his services should be discontinued before that date. The Department will rely on you to make an endeavour to economize in this regard.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, with regard to the amount paid Joseph Robert, furnace man at the St. Francis R. C. School during the past winter.

It is my duty to let you know that if nothing is done to the surroundings and to the schoolhouse itself, before long, the building will be out of use. An inspector of houses is absolutely needed.

Mr. Thomas of Pierrefonds tells me he has just one tank of the size needed (40 gal.) and that we could have it fitted.

I believe we should take it immediately as I am told it is a very bad proposition to find hot water tanks actually.

An immediate answer would help.

Dear Sir:

The present is to inform you that the school building needs repairing from the basement to the roof.
Water runs into the coal bin quite abundantly and the coal cannot be brought in before such repairs are being made.
Water runs also into the house at different places whenever it rains and especially at the melting of the snow, this spring, it was a real flood in the house.

The roof was greatly damaged by the falling of big pieces of ice, this spring.

There has been lately, a considerable landslip near the house. Very likely another will occur if care is not taken at once. We suggest that an officer should come for inspection and to make an estimate of the cost, as it is impossible for us to do so.

Hoping you will do your best to obtain from the Dept. a prompt and favourable answer,

We remain, gratefully yours,

[Signature]
Superior.

The pump slide should also be attended to.

Will you please attend to this matter at once.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

It has been quite a task to find a competent man to finish our work, who was to be done immediately at St. Joseph's Academy.

Mr. Secretary having been sick a part of the summer I felt lucky to have been able to bring him over to the school.

First of all he finds that the cellar walls will have to be cemented inside & outside from the floor to about a foot above the ground in a butt of about 50 feet high or less, so the water seeps after each rain.

The roof over the lower part of the house, what we call the Office, will have to be nailed and covered with a good coat of cement paint.

That Mr. Secretary is willing to do for about $75.00

The roof over the other parts of the house will have to be treated the same way, as quantities have to be treated the same way, as quantities have been peeled off by the ice, and nails have been pulled out by the ice, and in some places the iron sheets have been torn up.
This matter why water was dripping in different places in the house. This job will cost between $175. or $180. at the least.

It is very important that this work be done without delay; as later on, I do not know if I would be able to get men to do it, and it is quite impossible to face another winter with the roof in this condition.

Please give an immediate attention to this matter, and I'll be

Yours truly,

[Signature]

M.B.Maurault, agent

Monsieur l'Agent,

L'an dernier, nous vous disions que le Couvent avait besoin de réparations du haut en bas, au dedans et au dehors; les plus urgentes ont été faites. Cependant, il en reste encore à faire. La maison n'est quasiment habitable.

L'hiver dernier, nous en avons beaucoup souffert: L'eau et le froid entraînaient à plusieurs endroits; et ce n'est qu'à force de chauffage et de bousillage que nous avons pu remédier à cet état de chose.

Dernièrement, le plafond d'une chambre est tombé en partie; et le reste menace de descendre.

La galerie a été aussi considérablement endommagée par l'eau; elle aurait besoin de réparation et de peinture. Je pourrais même ajouter, que toute la maison, au dehors comme au dedans, aurait besoin de peinture.

Veuillez s.v.p. Monsieur l'Agent, user de toute votre influence, afin d'obtenir du Département, que les réparations les plus nécessaires soient faites cet été.

Espérant une réponse favorable,

Nous sommes, Monsieur l'Agent,
Les SS.Grisées de la Croix

Espérant une réponse favorable,

Nous sommes, Monsieur l'Agent,

Dr. B. Maurault, Indian Agent, Pierreville, Que.

In your letter of June 12 you brought to our attention certain repairs required at the St. Francois R.C. Day School. As you are aware, Mr. Doucet subsequently visited this school and he states that the following repairs should be considered at the present time:

1. Southwest corner of the school above the office to be repaired;
2. Row of bricks above flashing of front porch to be pointed;
3. Interior of office to be decorated;
4. In one room the ceiling to be plastered at broken places and the whole room redecorated;
5. Another room with damaged ceiling to be redecorated;
6. If possible the ceiling of the building should be insulated with rock wool.

The Department desires you to have a competent contractor give us an estimate of doing the above work, but we feel that the total amount should be much less than the amount mentioned in your letter of June 12.
Mr. Doucet also states that in future the roof should be kept clear of snow at all times. This might involve making some wooden scrapers. You might let me know what these would cost.

R.A. Hoey,

Pierreville, October 22, 1943.

Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: The Repair of the Odanak Convent

I understand that the amount payable is higher than the estimate, for there were many things which we had not expected.

M.B. Maurault, Agent,

Dear Agent:

When Mr. Doucet visited the schools last April he noticed that three rooms should be repaired this year. Moreover the exterior of the building has been greatly damaged by usage and especially by the mobility of the ground. These repairs should have been done a long time ago and it is, I believe, in the interests of the Department to have them done as soon as possible.

Last year we asked to have the porch repaired and nothing was done.

It would require about $50 for the general cleaning of the classrooms, the corridors and the hall.

I beg of you, dear Agent, to make these several requests at your earliest possible convenience.

Hoping that these gentlemen will understand the necessity to take care of the upkeep of their building, I remain,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Sister M. Josephine,

Dr. B. Maurault, Indian Agent, Pierreville, Que.

I have your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing letter from Sister Josephine with reference to additional repairs required at the St. Francis R.C. School. I also note the request for $50 for general cleaning of the whole building. The Department considers this amount excessive, as in past years only $25 has been requested for the same purpose. However, it may be more difficult to have this work done at the present time, due to shortage of labour, and an amount of $35 will be allowed for the purpose this year.

The Department has just received a letter dated the 10th instant from Mrs. Maurault with reference to certain repairs that are required to the kitchen in the Sisters' living quarters at the St. Francis R.C. School.

Last July we received a quotation from Mr. Descoteaux regarding certain repairs that were considered necessary at the St. Francis R.C. School. Dear Sir:

I have some difficulty with the Shawinigan Water & Power Co on account of a bill to the amount of $19.41 for service period ending the 22 of December 1944. This regards service rendered to St-Francis school.

Courchesne, the Sorel office manager came yesterday to settle the matter with me. I still doubt we owe them that amount.

By the record book I find no place for that amount of $19.41. On the 5th of January I sent to Ottawa a bill of $17.36, which, in my opinion, covers the service period ending the 22 of December 1944.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th of June, I went with a tinsmith to look over the verandah of the St-Francis R.C. School. This man states the wood work and metal are good. The trouble is that, the metal is nailed in places with nails having lead washers and it is where the roof leaks. With a little plastic on these nails the trouble will be over.

Regarding the office roof, it is much more serious than I thought first. The office is covered with galvanized iron, which, for repairing purpose, was coated with pitch. This pitch shells here and there and metal sheets are cut in many places especially on the ribs.

The tinsmith says new roof ought to be done.

Here is his estimates:
Labour for one man to remove old iron..........................8.75
600 pounds of galvanized iron at $9.00 per sq. ft..............54.00
tin, acid, gazoline, nails, elastic gum.........................3.00
Tinsmith's wages.............................................30.00

The tinsmith suggests that the roof of the whole building should be painted. That roof was painted once, the paint shells in some places, but we see no rust spots. So I think we can wait at least until next year. May be the conditions will be better at that time, laborers being more available.

About galvanized iron sheets the tinsmith told me a permit is needed to buy them. Can the Department secure that permit?

Yours truly,

Dr. Michel Tetreault,
Indian Agent

The above noted voucher is returned as it would not appear to be properly made out.

Chief Treasury Officer
Ottawa, January 24, 1946.

Dr. M. Tetreault, Indian Agent, Pierreville, Quebec.

I am returning the attached voucher covering the cost of water services at the St. Francis H.C. Day School for the period June 1st, 1945 to June 1st, 1946. It is noted that the Company requests $50.00. Formerly we only paid $25.00 a year and we did not appear to have given any authority for increasing the cost of the services. You should, therefore, submit a new voucher for $25.00.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Pierreville, January 31st, 1946.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of January 24th instant, with regard to the amount requested for the water services at the St-Francis R.C. Day school.

I have seen Mr. Art. Tramblay, the manager of the water-works and he states that the price for supplying with water this school is $50.00 a year since 1930.

In the record book, during the administration of Dr. Maurault, I see voucher No. 103, dated January 14, 1943, covering the cost of water services at the above named school. The amount is $50.00. Of course I don't know if this amount has been paid or not.

I return my voucher with the invoice because Mr. Tramblay says he is sure the price is $50.00.

Yours truly,

Dr. Michel Létourneau,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 5, 1946.

Dr. Michael Tetreault,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, Que.

I regret that it is necessary to again return
the account for the water service at the St. Francis R.C.
School. On your voucher you request that the cheque be
sent to Arthur Tremblay while the account accompanying
the voucher states that Ludger Cloutier is the owner.
It therefore appears that the voucher should be drawn in
favour of Ludger Cloutier instead of in favour of
Arthur Tremblay.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Je regrette de vous importuner avec les réparations
de réparations déjà faites il y a quelques années et renouvelées depuis sans que vous y ayez donné suite.

Voici l'enumeration:

2- Réparation de la galerie.

Je serais aussi soulagé à votre approbation
certains autres réparations que je considère comme urgentes:

2- Réparation du plafond de la chapelle et d'une chambre.
3- Recouvrir le toit de la maison.
4- Couvrir de plastique le plancher de l'école menagère.
5- Repasser ou renouveler poêle de cuisine.

Comme la saison est déjà avancée, j'espère que vous
donnerez une prompte attention à ma requête.

Vous remerciant à l'avance de votre bienveillante et

Cher monsieur,

À mon retour de la conférence de Québec, je me suis occupé du toit du couvent d'Edanak.

D'abord j'ai eu la visite de deux hommes de la compagnie Guy Laval de Nicolet. Je suis allé avec eux à Ottawa. Ils ont été sur le point examiner la situation et ont été voir dans le grenier. Ils n'ont fait le report cinquième, ni ces hommes ont trouvé la compagnie n'a pas voulu soumissionner. Cette compagnie s'occupe de toitures, mais sa spécialité est surtout les systèmes de chauffage.

Il ne fait pas de chaleur en autre homme. M. Edmond Beyer de Terrebonne m'a donné sa soumission (elle est incluse). Sa spécialité est de peinturer les échelles et les volets des églises. Il me semble que sa soumission est un peu floue.

Enfin j'ai fait voir mon ferblantier de St-François-du-Lac, Marcel Beyer. Pour lui des vis toutes telles que supérieures à Guy Laval, qui ne veut pas cher. Il propose une couverture neuve et il a soumis l'offre pour 10 livres de tôle (1000 pieds carrés) au prix de $10.00 par couvre. Il dit qu'il faut payer le prix de la couverture, c'est-à-dire la partie à côté de la rivière et celle au sud de l'église. Ces deux parties feraient nous payer lors de la commission du couvent le couvert en neuf. Je crois que la soumission de M. Beyer est beaucoup plus vantée que celle de M. Beyer. Il ne demande pas beaucoup plus cher et il nous fait un toit neuf. J'ai plus de
confiance à une couverture neuve ou de la peinture sur une visille tôle.

Et le moment le soit de coûte aux meilleurs de ces deux parties ci-dessus mentionnées, l'un tard, l'autre les conditions seront meilleures, nous pourrons couvrir le reste si le besoin s'en fait sentir.

Le service est pas le tôle en stock, mais il serait bon de pouvoir être en fin de compte. Il ne dit, il est trouvé trop cher que des nouvelles durant l'hiver, si on lui accorde le temps, il nous dit il voit aussi tôt un possible afin de lui permettre de nous aider pour couvrir cet automne. C'est urgent; le temps est emménagé dans la chapelle et dans une chambre.

La clôture qui entoure le coude du couvent est en très mauvais état. Quand j'ai fait mes estimations, j'ai fixé le prix de cette clôture à 785,00. Ce qu'elle a été faite à meilleur compte, elle n'y a certainement encore pas été faite à l'année, elle est donc en mauvais état. Elle est basée sur la tête des arbres. La broche est tombée, elle est détruite. Il y a un bout près du couvent qui est complètement terre. C'est très disgracieux.

J'inclus une lettre de la soeur supérieure me demandant certaines réparations.

Pour la galerie de même que pour le fond de la chapelle et de la chambre il faut tenir compte que le toit de la maison soit repéré avant. Les murs de la salle à manger, de l'escalier, du corridor et ceux des chambres sont les mêmes ici et là. Il faudrait réparer ces fissures et peindre les murs et le fonds.

10 gallons de peinture....................... 10.0

Total........................................... $184.00
Le plancher de l'école mesure une superficie de 10 verges carrées. Pour le couvrir de revêtement, il faudrait 4 verges de longueur à verger de largeur. Je dis encore que si elle veut voir du revêtement en plus de 4 verges de largeur, elle doit de 2 à 3 verges pour plus. Ce plancher doit coûter au moins 100,00.

Quant au toit de la cuisine, je peux me faire une idée de ce qu'elle a fait faire un électricien pour le réparer et de combien cela peut être coûteux, mais je ne peux pas dire à quel prix. Il faut faire des estimations correctes, mais elles doivent être faites par un professionnel, car les travaux de réparation de toiture sont coûteux et nécessitent des compétences spécifiques. Si elle souhaite économiser sur le coût total de cette réparation, elle pourrait envisager de faire appel à une société d'électricité locale ou à une entreprise de travaux publics qui peut offrir des prix plus bas.

Je peux vous aider à trouver des conseils avisés et des informations utiles.

Je reste,

Votre dévoué,

Dear Sir,

The Grey Nuns asked me again this year to stoke the furnaces of the convent at Odanak. I have begun doing that work. Now, I would ask you to increase my salary which was set at $15 per month fifteen years ago. Do you not think that it would be reasonable to give me more. The cost of living is much higher now. Mr. Marcel Crevier, tinsmith of St-Francois du Lac when he contracted the roof of the St. Francis Day School, had figured that 10 squares of iron sheet would be necessary for the job and he set his price accordingly. The iron sheets being not available the contract was changed for aluminium.

With reference to the repairs to the roof of the St. Francis R.C. School, we are returning your voucher No. 112.

Please prepare a new voucher to which you should attach a written quotation from Marcel Crevier to provide the roofing and labour in connection with its installation, for an amount of $257.00.

In reviewing your letter of the 31st ultimo it is difficult for us to decide why the contractor made such a mistake in figuring the quantity of material required. In your letter of June 5th you stated that the price had increased to $257.00 and we authorized this expenditure.

Now you state that the amount mentioned only covers half the roof, although both your letters intimated that the amount previously authorized would be sufficient to cover the whole roof.

Mr. Doucet hopes to be in your vicinity some time within the next month and will inspect the school and decide what further work, if any, is necessary.

Dear Sir,

On last visit of Mr. Boucet at Lacerville Indian Reserve, it was suggested to improve the supply of water at the above named school, to use a well dug by the missionary last year and approximately 125 feet distant from the school. The missionary is willing to let the sisters have the well provided they install a hand pump for his use.

It was decided to enlarge this well, to cement it, lay a trench and install an electric pump in the school cellar. Mr. Boucet asked me to look for the prices and estimates of these different items and submit a report. That is what I did except for the report. The reason is that forgetting anything, I needed it was impossible to assure in the short time. The water was analyzed by the Provincial Laboratory and was declared "safe" (Report enclosed). It is believed that this water is contaminated by the soil travelling up and down to fetch water used by the defective covering of the wells. This may be the reason of the contamination of this water.

In the meantime the priest has installed an electric pump in the cellar of his house. He drove a pipe with a joint attached to the lower end right into the ground of the cellar and he reached water about 18 feet in depth. I was watching this very closely, after it had worked 3 or 4 weeks satisfactorily I urged the priest to have the other installed. He did so and I have just received the report yesterday. The report is declared "good" by the samples taken from the tap. The others samples come from a pump installed next to the electric pump and to be used in case the electric version stops; this happen sometimes. This pump is new and has not been used except to assure if it was functioning good. It may happen the same found by analysis were in the pump before its installation and the fact that the pump has not been used enough to wash them out.
I would suggest this kind of installation instead than use the wells close the school, which I intended to use in the first place. Here we have no site or place, no trench to dig, much less rise to buy and much less labour today. Of course I cannot guarantee to kill strike water today. This is rather speculative. But it is a good risk to take, I believe. We can use a hand pump first, have the water analysed and if all five satisfaction, install the electric pump. To drive a line about 12 feet in depth will cost about one man day. I have one hand pump I could lend for that and I think we could borrow a stat.

There has been developments regarding the Inuvik Waterworks lately. For many years there has been much interest between Mr. Cleary, owner of Inuvik Waterworks, and the Municipality of Inuvik concerning the water supply to the population. For the last few years Inuvik has been searching for water in the ground. A last test they have succeeded, according to the advice of the experts they have three plots where three additional wells could be installed with an output of one million gallons per day and the other two 75,000 each. This is very interesting for the need of Inuvik and Canada is 10,000 to 150,000 daily.

I had an interview with the Mayor about this. They are planning agreements with the farms to have the water in the village outside of the village. They are planning a refer due and it is question to buy additional land to add repair or rebuild this waterworks. The water was analysed at "Leduc" and the council seems to be a mood to speed up things, but it will take many months before we have that water at our taps.

Enclosed are different kind of systems and suggestions for installation. I think there are enough explanations and illustrations to make it clear.

Mr. John Lemieux sells the Macgillivray system, he has enclosed a sketch. Mr. Lemieux is doing his business by the county, and he has in addition to our scheme, the water in the wells is for the district and not the continuous operation of the plant. I am in favour of the idea for in a month or two we will have all the population have water there and I wonder if the wells will be sufficient.

Note: Mr. Lemieux sells Macgillivray pump, but recommend the Johnson pump-dam installation as for Lemieux.

Dear Mr. Boisvert:

This is with reference to your letter of August 13th and our conversation of October 14th with regard to the water supply at Odanak.

This matter is somewhat complicated. It was hoped to secure a water supply for the school from the well dug by the missionary last year, but unfortunately analysis showed that the water from this well was contaminated and unsafe. Subsequently, it seems the missionary installed an electric pump in the cellar of his house with which he used an artesian well securing water at a depth of about fifteen feet, which on analysis was declared good.

It has been suggested by the Indian Agent that a similar plan might be followed at the school. The whole matter will be investigated by our Supervisor of Vocational Training, Mr. A. J. Doucet, who will be at Odanak at a very early date.

As you are aware, this whole question of bad water in the vicinity of Odanak and Pierreville is an extremely important one and as I mentioned to you several members of our staff have become ill, in one case seriously. What solution there could be for the whole difficulty both for the Indians and other members of the community is difficult to say.

On the immediate question of the school water supply, however, you will be advised further as soon as a report has been received from Mr. Doucet.

Re: St. Francis R.C. Indian Day School. Your File (23)

We have your letter of the 14th instant with reference to the payment for the water used at the above school.

On February 20th, 1948, you issued Voucher No. 31 for an amount of $50.00 in favour of Ludger Cloutier. This Voucher read as follows: "For waterworks service at St. Francis Day School from June 1st 1947 to June 1st 1948".

Cher monsieur,

Je viens vous donner des nouvelles de notre puits du couvent d'Odanak.

Lundi matin le Docteur Faucher a pris des échantillons de l'eau de ce puits pour fin d'analyse. Il ne s'attend pas à ce que le résultat soit favorable. Il dit que la chose principale est d'avoir de l'eau dans ce genre de puits. Et voici comment on procède. On finit le puits, ensuite on le désinfecte avec du chlorure de Chaux, on vide le puits 3 ou 4 fois et on prend ensuite des échantillons d'échantillons et en a beaucoup de chance que l'eau soit déclarée bonne. Il ne voit pas pourquoi l'eau ne serait pas bonne à la profondeur où nous la prenons.

Après votre téléphone de l'autre jour il a plu et comme le trou que nous avons creusé menaçait de débouler j'ai demandé aux hommes de descendre les tuyaux de béton aussi bas que possible. Ils ont travaillé environ une journée.

Le deuxième tuyau en partant d'en bas est à peu près au niveau de l'eau. Ils ont mis deux tuyaux par dessus, ainsi qu'il se produit un déboulis on ne perdra pas l'ouvrage qui est fait. Les tuyaux sont couverts avec des planches pour empêcher la terre de tomber dedans.

Le puits a 18 ou 19 pieds de profondeur. Il y a 3 pieds et 10 pouce d'eau dedans, la première feuille de tuyau se remplit en 1/2 heure. Maintenant si on doit continuer les travaux il va falloir se hâter parce la gelée ne doit pas être loin. Il a neige hier et aujourd'hui. Il est vrai qu'il ne fait pas très froid encore mais la température peut changer beaucoup du soir au matin à cette époque de l'année.

Votre dévoue

Aquamatic Operation

Double pipe Aquamatics combine two pumping principles — a vertical motor-driven centrifugal pump located at the well surface and a hydraulic jet located below the water level in the well. The only moving pump part is the impeller, located above ground in the pump. The hydraulic jet, operating in conjunction with the centrifugal pump, delivers water from the well to the pump, which in turn delivers the water under pressure to the storage tank. A small percentage of the water removed from the well is returned under pressure by the centrifugal pump to the hydraulic jet, thereby enabling it to raise more water from the well. The entire operation is a smooth, automatic, continuous flow. Per dollar invested, Aquamatics give you superior lift per horsepower and deliver more gallons per hour for a given set of conditions.

HOW TO SELECT YOUR DOUBLE PIPE AQUAMATIC

Find gallons per hour (GPH) needed from water requirements chart (Page 1). Measure pumping level at your well — that is, number of feet from pump head to water while pumping. Under "pumping level" column, choose the next deeper column. Example: If your pumping level is 65, use "70" column. Reading down in "70" column, choose GPH you need.

Read across in your GPH column to get minimum inside diameter of well and the catalog order number.

EQUIPMENT FURNISHED: Pump complete with motor (60 cycle, single phase, 115/230 volt), pressure control valve, air volume control, pressure switch, air volume control, pressure gauge, jet assembly, foot valve, slip coupling and fittings to connect pump to air volume control.
**EASIER INSTALLATION—WIDER CHOICE OF SITES**

Flexibility of installation possible only in Aquamatics is guaranteed by the exclusive design of the pump head.

Two pipe outlets in the head sidewall are provided for offset installations, permitting straightforward connection of drive and discharge pipes without reducing sizes or capacities. This feature makes installation much easier by eliminating the need of awkward elbows and costly special construction—modestly commonly needed for offset applications with conventional pump designs.

Bottom outlets provided for Aquamatic over the well installations are simply plugged when the pump is off the well; side connections are available when the unit is installed. This pump head design, plus Aquamatic streamlined styling and exceptionally tough construction, are features that give you the widest possible choice of location sites.

Aquamatic tanks can be placed in home, basement, or barn to protect them from unexpected freezing spells, and to make them easy of access during all kinds of weather. Or they can be as easily placed in a well pit or pump houses. Whatever the site problems of your locality, Aquamatic flexibility will make the solution easier—at lower cost.

Dear Sir:

Re: St-Francis R.C. Day School water system
Odanak P.Q.

On last visit of Mr. Doucet at Pierreville Indian Reserve it was question, to improve the supply of water at the above named school, to use a wells dug by the missionary last year and approximately 125 feet distant from the school. The missionary is willing to let the sisters have the wells provided we install a hand pump for his use.

It was decided to enlarge this wells, to cement it, dig a trench and install an electric pump in the school cellar. Mr. Doucet asked me to look for the prices and estimates of these different items and submit a report. That is what I did except for the report. The reason is that before starting anything I guessed it was preferable to assure if the water was good. The water was analyzed by the Provincial Laboratory and was declared "Unsafe" (Report enclosed). It is believed that this water is contaminated by the pail travelling up and down to fetch water and by the defective covering of the wells. This may be the reason of the contamination of this water.

In the meantime the priest had installed an electric pump in the cellar of his house. He drove a pipe with a point attached to its lower end right into the ground of the cellar and he reached water about 15 feet in depth. I was watching this very closely. After it had worked 2 or 3 weeks satisfactorily I asked to the priest to have the water analyzed. He did so and I have just received the report yesterday. The report is declared "Good" by the samples taken from the tap. The other samples come from a pump installed next to the electric pump and to be used in case the electric service stop; this happen sometimes. This pump is new and has not been used except to assure if it was functioning good. It may happen the germs found by analysis were in the pump before its installation and that the pump has not been used enough to wash them out.

I would suggest this kind of installation instead than use the wells close the school which we intended to use in the first place. Here we have no wells to enlarge, no trench to dig, much less pipe to buy and much less labour to pay. Of course
I cannot guarantee we will strike water surely. This is rather capricious. But it is a good risk to take, I believe. We can use a hand pump first, have the water analyzed and if all give satisfaction, install the electric pump. To drive a pipe about 15 feet in depth will cost about one man day. I have one hand pump I could lend for that and I think we could borrow a point.

There happen new developments regarding the Pierreville water works lately. For many years there has been much quarrel between Ludger Cloutier, owner of Pierreville waterworks, and the Municipality of Pierreville concerning the water supplied to the population. For the last years Pierreville has been searching for water in the ground and last week they have succeeded. According to the sayings of the engineer they have three spots where three artesian wells could be installed with a capacity of one 50,000 gallons per day and the other two 75,000 each. This is very interesting for the need of Pierreville and Odanak is 110,000 to 120,000 daily.

I had an interview with the Major about this. They are planning agreements with the farmers where the water is (The water is a mile outside of the village). They are preparing a referendum and it is question to buy Cloutier's interests and repair or rebuild this waterworks. The water was analyzed and declared "Good". The council seems to be a mood to speed up things, but it will take many months before we have that water at our taps.

Enclosed are different kind of systems and suggestions with estimates. I think there are enough explanations and illustrations to make it clear.

1o--John Meunier sells the McDougall system, he has enclosed a sketch. All what is drawn in blue is furnished by the company, and what is in red is at our expense. The pump on the wells is for the priest's use and the fontaine Hydrant on the right corner is suggested for the use of the village accommodation. I am not in favour of the item for in a month or two we will have all the population take water there and I wonder if the wells will be sufficient.

2o--J.L. Bourbonniere sells McDougall pump, but recommend the Johnson pump--same installation as for Meunier

3o--Shooner & Cie sells the Southern pump
4o--Rene Mondou sells the same pump Southern like Shooner at same price. Mr. Mondou installs the pumps of all these firms. Mr. Mondou gave me a price for the whole business if we use a point. He will furnish:

1 Southern pump with a 120 tallons tank
Pipe required, 3 points (he says 3 points are more effective than one), electric installation and place the point or points. The whole will cost approximately $250.00 if he strikes water at the first time. If he has to look for water the price will vary.

All these pumps submitted here can work as well with points or in the wells outside.

I hope all these details will be useful to you.

Yours truly,

(sgd) Dr. Michel Tetreault
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Miss Gallagher, teacher of the St. Isidore Road School, has sent me a notice of her marriage, which took place on the 30th ultimo. She has not sent in her resignation however and I understand that she wishes to remain on till the end of the school year, June 30th, next.

An application for the position of teacher of this school has been made by a Miss Charlebois, who has had previous experience. She refers to Mr. T. P. Foran, K.C., of Hull and Mr. Chene of this Department for reference as to her qualifications. I have called Mr. Foran up on the phone and he told me that Miss Charlebois was a highly educated woman of excellent character and that she had been employed as stenographer in his office and in the Superior Court in Hull and he assured me that we would be very fortunate in obtaining her services. Mr. Chene also spoke very highly of her.

Her application was made for the St. Isidore Road School and, if Mrs. Grow, nee Gallagher, were out of the way, I would recommend her appointment. When I visited
visited the school last November I reported that the conditions there were not satisfactory and that I considered that it would be to the advantage of the pupils if another teacher were secured. The only question is how long Mrs. Grow should be allowed to remain.

Miss Charlebois would, from the inquiries I have made, be an acquisition to our teaching staff as she is a middle aged woman of experience. I would suggest that she be offered either the St. Regis Island or the Cornwall Island schools, the latter of which will be vacant on the 31st of March, next, temporarily and be given charge of the St. Isidore Road School as soon as Mrs. Grow is disposed of. Since the above was written I have learned that Miss Gallagher married an American, whose home is at Hogansburg.

My dear Sir,

On Tuesday, Jan. 9th, I visited Miss Descoteau's school and spent the afternoon investigating the pros and cons of her unique situation. She had sixteen pupils present, and they appeared to be well disciplined. I could not examine the class as there were too many other details to which I had to give my attention.

I discussed the question of a janitor with her, but she seemed quite unwilling to have any of the neighbors around do the work. I therefore selected a large school boy and asked him if he would help the teacher bring in coal and especially sift the ashes. Since the furnaces have been lighted, these are thrown outside the building and are carried all around the place. It serves as an amusement for the pupils to jump up and down the pile. The boy promised to help and I put him on trial for a week.

On Monday, the 8th, I sent a workman out there to see what would be needed and it will certainly require three or four days' labor to get the school in condition to avoid having all the fuel in store before the middle of February. Wind panes broken, doors off hinges slamming with the wind, etc., etc., the pipe leading from the sink was frozen and burst, the pump out of order, etc., etc. I had the broken pipe removed and we fixed another here with piping we had on hand and which will be put in place to-morrow. It would have cost a small fortune to get a plumber from Montreal out there.

After a careful investigation I think that the following articles should be supplied:

- 1 door mat (straw or cocoa, for the school)
- 1 thermometer
- 2 roller towel fixtures (they are hanging on nails)
- 1 dozen roller towels or towelling to make them
- 2 drinking cups
- 6 spring roller blinds for the class room windows

Kate Lebongne refuses to give up the blankets because she claims the teacher owes her money and she will hold on to them until she is paid.

The comforter belongs to the Department and it has been repaired but the man is also holding on to it until he is paid. In the meantime the teacher claims she is freezing. I shall send her out a few of our blankets until these minor matters are adjusted.
In your communication of Jan. 2, No.5-6-1, you state that the Department will allow the sum of $5.00 per month for janitor services at St. Isidore Road School. If I understand correctly Miss Descoteau draws $50.00 per year for janitor services which she performs herself. Is this amount in order to a surplus or is it included in her salary? I promised to pay the boy I selected to help the teacher but did not specify how much. I would like to know if it is to come out of Miss Descoteau's allowance or out of a surplus the Department allows.

I have induced Miss Descoteau to have her laundry done here in the village as she is not fitted up for the purpose. Melting snow to wash is not very pleasant work at this season.

The floor of the classroom is not very neat looking but the trouble is that last fall it was oiled before it was washed and it is now next to impossible to clean it. It will require a few years of washing to get the oil off, and have the school floor as neat as those of our village schools. I shall see to the washing of the roller towels and the school as this is the only safe way to get things done right.

I found Miss Descoteau's residence a real little gem of cleanliness, order and comfort, but in view of the quantity of coal used there I strongly insisted that one fire was quite enough to keep her house warm, and suggested her using the living room as a kitchen etc. for the cold weather.

I have every hope that once we get things organized there and the most essential work done there will be little room left for complaints.

Yours respectfully,

I have been struggling with my thoughts since yesterday, but my mind has finally reached a decision, and I give my request a kind consideration.

I beg of you, dear Superior, to nominate me as teacher in the St. Odile Road School. A full year has elapsed since my demission, unable to forget my former school and pupils, so pardon me stating, but the parents will certainly welcome my return.

Probably you were informed that I was dismissed through report of someone whose identity I am not aware, the report being that I was married, which prevented me from performing my duties properly. Oh dear Superior, if you could only realize the extent of this false accusation! I was so anxious in my work not only in the school room, but for general welfare of the locality. It took me almost a full term!
To organize that school and to bring to surface any ambition to them from the minds of parents and children, as a result I obtained a fair average and children came readily to school, my reward was simply my dismissal.

At present I am in perfect health and my children can never interfere in my work.

Kindly reply and give me a ray of hope, wishing you every success.

I remain,

Yours truly,
Lena Jacobs
Kangshawega
Que.

P.O. Box 156

M.B. Copy which I forgot to enclose in my letter yesterday.

Sr. Mary Gabriel
My dear Sir,

I am enclosing a letter received from Mrs Jacobs, former teacher at the St. Isidore Road School. I am not in need of a teacher to know where Jacobs was dismissed by the Department, and consequently refer her application to you for evaluation.

I have given considerable time to finding a qualified teacher for this school, but all efforts have as yet been unsuccessful. No one outside the Reserve is willing to go there and live the life of isolation for such small salaries. I realize that the compensation is quite sufficient for the number of pupils attending, (I never found more than ten pupils present at any time), but in Montreal and all around here qualified teachers get between $600.00 and $900.00 per annum. You understand that none of these will go to the wilds of Caughnawaga and live there for $350.00. We must take someone from the Reserve, and because she would be qualified and longing to take charge there, and since the old ones are married, I have now in view a girl of about twenty-six, Margaret Reid, who has been acting as Assistant teacher in our schools here for the last eight years. She has no diploma, but her experience is worth a great deal. I will receive a definite answer from her this week. I have another lady with a Quebec Diploma, who would willingly take the school, but she is recently given birth to a child and, of course, I hesitate to consider her although she assures me she will have somebody with her to care for the child. This young woman is a Graduate of our schools, and taught here for a few years with marked success.

I would like to know if you sincerely object to married women being in charge providing she is perfectly satisfied and has somebody to care for the child during school hours. I have most confidence in this young woman as she is very ambitious and knows just how to handle the children. Her husband, who works on bridges etc., would be free during the winter to help her out with the work of heating, etc.

A word of explanation would be greatly appreciated.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Russell T. Perrier,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

My dear Sir,

You doubtless received my letter relative to the engagement of a teacher for St. Isidore Road School as well as the application of Mrs. Lena Jacobs. Since then I received a definite reply from Margaret Revis, presently Assistant Teacher in our Village School, and she will accept to teach at the St. Isidore Road School for the salary presently paid Miss Desjardins.

She is the best available here and I have confidence that the Department will be satisfied with her work. She has an unmarried sister who will live with her during the winter and look after her interests.

During the first months of the school term,
I had considerable trouble with some of the French
children of St. Isidore Road School. Their parents were
prejudiced against the teacher and made her task
unbearable. I visited the school often and gave her
every assistance possible. As Mr. Jocks is seldom home,
I played the part of truant-officer and went to see the
parents who live at the far end of the Reserve. Nothing
could convince them of their false judgments, and as
they were determined to hold their own opinion and
continue to make trouble I was forced to report the case
to the Agent who settled them with a fine. Now peace
reigns in the school and the teacher can control her
pupils and command respect.

Ottawa, January 16, 1929.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to conditions at the Caughnawaga schools. I note, with regret, that considerable time has been lost because of sickness on the reserve; but I trust that interruptions from now on will be comparatively few.

You refer to the extension of the privilege of teaching French to the St. Isidore and Bush Schools. Please note that this addition to the instruction is not obligatory but is left to the discretion of the teacher. In the case of the St. Isidore Road School, I note you believe the teaching of French is impractical. Therefore, it is not necessary to add it to the course of studies at the present time.

I regret there are no funds for the purpose of increasing the salaries of Miss Snow and Miss Phillips.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

ON THE ST. ISIDORE ROAD SCHOOL

As well as I could understand she was engaged for $55.00 per month or $550.00 per year, and she claims that the quarter ending December 31st was not paid in full. She received, I think, $197.00 instead of $165.00. It seems there was some difficulty over purchases she made at Goodwin's Limited, and the Department refused to pay for some of the articles which were considered either unnecessary or too expensive. This, she says, amounted to $36.50 and some odd cents. Admitting that the Department did deduct the amount there still remains a balance due her.
OTTAWA, January 30th, 1925.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th instant, furnishing the Department with a report on your visit to the St. Isidore Road School. We note that conditions are now fairly satisfactory, and that the teacher's residence is comfortable and well furnished.

I enclose herewith a list of the goods supplied for the use of the teacher's residence. This list includes the articles obtained by the teacher which were considered excessive; the cost of which were deducted from her salary. I am sure you will see that we were quite generous in the list of articles supplied and paid for. The articles charged against the teacher's salary are her personal property, and when she leaves school she will certainly take them with her. We discussed this matter with Miss Desrochers when she was in the Department, and she fully understood our position in the matter. We note that you will take an inventory of the articles on hand, and that you will see that everything is marked and stored away during the summer holidays, in order that the teacher taking charge next year may not have to be furnished with any extra supplies.

Regarding salary, Miss Desrochers began duties September 5th, and was paid one month's salary - $24.00 - for the month of September. For the quarter ending December 31st, 1924, she was paid at the quarterly rate for the year, viz: $17.50, from which a deduction was made for the goods purchased by her from Godwin's Limited, which were considered excessive, to the amount of $6.00. A cheque for the balance due, to the amount of $11.50, was sent her. For the current quarter, she will be paid at the quarterly rate, and at the end of the June quarter, if she remains until that time, her salary will be adjusted, and she will receive her full yearly salary. She is not paid monthly, but quarterly.

Regarding payment of the $5 per month for janitor services, a boy to say that we will forward the cheques to you, upon receipt of a voucher from the Agent for the amount due, which may be sent in monthly or quarterly, as desired. We note that you will pay the boy who does the work at the end of each week. We hope that the arrangements you have made for the caretaking will prove satisfactory to yourself and the teacher.

We -

Sister Mary Gabriel,
Supervising Principal,
Caughnawaga Indian Schools,
CAUGHNAWAGA, P.Q.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I respectfully submit to your attention that the furnaces of the two schools, Bush and St. Isidore Road as well as the kitchen stove at the residence of the St. Isidore Road School, being almost out of service it would be necessary to replace them. There is no doubt that the coke is the cause of the prompt deterioration of the furnaces and stoves of the schools of Caughnawaga.

The approximate cost of the furnaces is $20.00 each and that of the kitchen stove is $50.00. I beg you to kindly authorize me to purchase these three stoves for a sum of $90.00.

Ottawa, September 24, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, requesting that new furnaces be supplied for the St. Isidore Road and Bush Schools on the Gaughnawaga Reserve, also a kitchen stove for the teacher's residence at St. Isidore Road, and giving an estimate of the cost.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the list to receive consideration, of two furnaces - one for the Bush School and one for the St. Isidore Road School. The cost should not, if possible, exceed your estimate of $20 each. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase and installation of the furnaces for each of the schools separately.

The Department is not prepared to supply a new kitchen stove for the teacher's residence at the St. Isidore Road School. If any minor repairs are required to the old stove at present in use, you may have same carried out, keeping all costs as low as possible. It is considered that the present stove should be satisfactory for the needs of the teacher during the coming winter.

You should instruct the caretakers at both schools that they are to see that proper care is taken in the handling of the furnaces and in the use of the coke. If proper care is taken in the use of coke, there should be no danger of any damage to the furnaces.

Please arrange to have the new furnaces installed in the above named schools as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

FOREWORD

Fifteen, or even ten years ago, the scientific insulation of homes was practically unknown. Fortunately was the man who could build brick walls high enough to break the force of winter's wind or within the shade of tall trees to give some measure of protection from summer's glaring sun.

Today, however, home insulation has become an exact science. John Manville, for over 37 years the leader in the field of industrial insulation, has developed a method of insulating which has completely changed old standards of living comfort. Your home, regardless of its age, whether it be brick, frame, plaster, stucco, clapboard or shingled, can be made a far more comfortable place than you ever dreamed possible.

But—and this is important—it is only through the scientific selection of the correct insulating material that these results can be obtained. To insure your receiving all the benefits that go with a properly insulated home, John-Manville recommends work only to qualified insulating engineers. These men located in all parts of Canada employ the special trouble-free blowing process by which John-Manville Rock Wool Insulation is installed. They have successfully insulated thousands of homes throughout Canada. John-Manville heartily endorses their ability to insulate your home in the most efficient manner known to modern science.

WHAT PRICE COMFORT?

You spend your life seeking bodily comfort for yourself and for your family, because you know that better health will result. Actually, you are seldom conscious of being comfortably. You instantly realize when you are uncomfortable. Whether you are at work, play, eat and sleep, your comfort and comfort to a large degree is governed by temperature. When you feel cold, you seek warmth. When you are hot, you seek coolness.

Most people think that they live in comfortable houses, but actually this is far from true. In spite of the most modern heating systems, there are usually cold, drafty, hard-to-heat rooms in which the summer the heat of the sun beat the jalousies so that they remain extremely uncomfortable long after sundown.

The purpose of insulating a house is to help prevent summer heat from penetrating through walls and roofs, and to help prevent interior heat in winter from escaping to the cool air outside. When this is scientifically done, homes are comfortable the year 'round and become healthier and more pleasant places in which to live.
**Why Your Home Should Be Insulated**

**WHAT IS HOME INSULATION?**
Home insulation is an effective barrier to the passage of heat from the home in winter and into the home in summer. Heat travels in one direction only—from warm areas to colder areas. In winter, when you turn on your furnace, the heat from your furnace leaks out of your house through the roof and walls; in summer, a reverse action takes place. Radiant heat from the sun penetrates through the roof and walls into your house.

**PROVIDES GREATER COMFORT**
Cold and heat have more to do with physical comfort than any other single factor. Uniform temperature in a home is the desire of every family. Without adequate home insulation it is practically impossible to maintain uniform temperature in the comfort zone during cold weather and hot heat in summer. With adequate home insulation it is quite easy to keep every room in the house at a more even temperature throughout the coldest spells in winter and up to 15° cooler in the sweltering heat of summer time.

**HEATING THE GREAT OUTDOORS IS EXPENSIVE**
Snow melts on the roof of Mr. Brown’s house when expensive heat leaks out. Snow never melts on the roof of Mr. Smith’s house because Johns-Manville Rock Wool keeps heat in—and this amazing material is just as effective in keeping the heat out in summer as it is in preventing the wasteful escape of heat in winter.

**REDUCES FUEL COSTS**
It is reasonable to suppose that, if the heat you generate in your furnace is retained in your home instead of being allowed to escape through the roof and walls, you will not have to generate as much heat to keep your home comfortable. This is actually the case. The experience of home owners who have insulated with Johns-Manville Rock Wool proves that you save up to 30% on your fuel. Proper home insulation will pay for itself in a very few seasons.

**PROMOTES BETTER HEALTH**
Uniform temperature and the elimination of draughts in a home are very important contributing factors to the health of the whole family. Many of the common colds, which too often develop into more serious illness, can be traced to draughts and careless heating. Draughts and cold air are caused by the current of warm air moving to the colder areas and the cold air being forced to the warm areas. Proper insulation brings about a more even temperature upstairs and downstairs, thereby preventing draughts.

**STOP THE PENETRATION OF HEAT AND COLD**
Every home, regardless of the type of wall construction, has a certain amount of heat loss through the walls. There is only a thin layer of air and plaster between the exposed surfaces of the walls and the outside air in winter and hot in summer. A blanket of Johns-Manville Rock Wool, properly installed by experienced Johns-Manville installation experts, provides an effective barrier against heat loss in winter and heat penetration in the summer.

**SUMMER HEAT IS HARD ON NERVES AND HEALTH**
Your house, regardless of how well insulated, offers little resistance to the passage of heat. Other than insulation it is properly installed, Johns-Manville Rock Wool lowers room temperatures in summer as much as 15 degrees and makes a noticeable difference in bedrooms, living rooms, kitchens, and dining rooms.

HERE IS WHY MORE CANADIAN HOMES ARE INSULATED WITH JOHNS-MANVILLE ROCK WOOL THAN ANY OTHER KIND

WHAT IS ROCK WOOL

Rock Wool is actually made from stone. Selected rock is melted at an extremely high temperature and then subjected to a jet of hot steam which "blows" it into soft, fibrous particles forming millions trapped air cells in each cubic inch of Rock Wool. These particles combine to form a lofty, woolly material.

INSULATION QUALITIES

The outstanding insulating value of Johns-Manville Rock Wool is due to the fact that the millions of tiny trapped air cells contained in each cubic inch of the wool are so small that they cannot be seen even under a microscope. The Bureau of Standards at Ottawa has established the efficiency of Rock Wool Insulation.

FIREPROOF

Johns-Manville Rock Wool is a mineral. It absolutely will not burn. Properly applied it mitigates the danger of fire in a house, because it fills the hollow places in a house that act as veritable flues in an uninsulated house.

PERMANENT

Johns-Manville Rock Wool Home Insulation will provide efficient insulation as long as your home stands. It is as permanent as the original rock from which it comes.

LIGHT WEIGHT

The lightweight fibers of Johns-Manville Rock Wool are extremely light and resilient and can be applied over any ceiling with perfect safety.

CLEAN

There is no vegetable content in Johns-Manville Rock Wool. Insects will not infest it and rodents will not nest in it. It is water resisting and will not rot or corrode.

I beg to refer to your letter of the 12th of July last, dealing with the St. Isidore Road School and in this connection to say that this School is now opened under the direction of Miss Desrochers.

In connection with the repairs needed please be advised that only minor repairs are required at the teacher's residence. However water should be supplied in the residence. This could be done by digging a ditch, below freezing level, from the well serving the School building to the residence a distance of about 50 feet and to supply the building with a hand pump and a sink. Please send your authorization.

Relative to the School building it would appear that the lack of insulation makes it most uncomfortable during the winter months. So much so that the children had to be sent away on many occasions during the past winters.

The most practical way to deal with this problem is believed to have the building insulated with Rock Wool, and in this connection you will find herewith an estimate from the Canadian Johns-Manville for this work, which was sent after their representative was requested to inspect the building. If this work is not done it is doubted if the children will be able to be received regularly or if the teacher will be able to teach at all during the cold winter days. Please let me know if the price submitted is acceptable.

(Frs. Brisebois)

December 5, 1947

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: St. Isidore Road School.

I wish to advise you that the old well at the above School has dried up and cannot be used any longer, with the result that both the School and the teacher's Residence are without water.

The present well is reported to have been drilled about 25 years ago and was located near the School building. It was hand drilled and a pipe of 1½ inches sunk at a depth of 25 feet.

As water is badly needed I would suggest that an artesian well be drilled as soon as possible which would supply the two buildings. It is estimated that a good supply of water could be found at a depth of not more than 40 feet. The price of $4.50 per foot, including the six inches pipe.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Re:- St-Isidore road School and Teacher's Residence.

You will find herewith prices furnished by Jolicoeur & Freres, Lachine, Que., covering the cost of repairs to the above School building and the Teacher's residence and in this connection to say that the Contractors had been requested to give us estimates on a limited number of needed repairs.

On the day they visited the place the undersigned was absent so they proceeded to the School where they met the teacher, Miss Descoteaux, who insisted that they submit prices on all kinds of repairs and new work that she had in mind should be done at that old School.

It would appear that the teacher believes that she will terminate her living days at that School and apparently is not aware of the fact that it is a possibility that the children attending her School could travel to the new School presently being built when it is ready, possibly in the course of next year. The last item on the contractor's list is the culminating point.

The repairs marked in red on the list enclosed are recommended being necessary. The balance should be disregarded.

(Ps. Brisebois)

F.J.G. Cunningham, Esq.,
Departmental Solicitor.

Re: St. Isidore Road Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Reserve.

I would refer to your memorandum of January 4, 1949, written in reply to our memorandum of December 6, 1948, re the estate of John Phillips and the Caughnawaga Bush Indian Day School.

In your said memorandum you gave an opinion to the effect that the Quit Claim Deed dated May 8, 1906, between John Phillips and His Majesty, King Edward the Seventh, as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, is void and, therefore, the bush school and the lot on which it is located belonged to John Phillips' Estate. It is my understanding in that particular case, it was said that when John Phillips released the property, he did so for so long as the land was used for school purposes and, therefore, was only paid the sum of $1.00 for the property.

We now have a somewhat similar situation regarding the St. Isidore Road Indian Day School which is located on parts of Reserve Lots 502 and 503. In this case the Indian owners of Lots 502 and 503 released forever their interest in the portions of the lots taken for the school lot and each received compensation at the rate of $50.00 per acre from the land taken from each of their holdings. Quit Claim Deeds were executed on July 17, 1911, between the two owners and His Majesty, King George the Fifth, as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The St. Isidore Road School is no longer used and the Education Division wish to dispose of it to an Indian or Indians. There was never any indication that the original owners of Lots 502 and 508 released the land for the school only for so long as it was used for school purposes as was intimated in the bush road school case. We contend that the owners knowingly released forever their possessory interest in the lands taken for the school lot and now that the lands and buildings are no longer required by the Education Division, they would automatically revert to Band ownership and can be sold or otherwise disposed of by the Band.

I should be very pleased to receive your comments in this matter.

Superintendent,

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

Re: St. Isidore Road Indian Day School

The above noted school is located on part of Reserve Lots 502 and 503, Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, and as it is no longer required for school purposes, and the Education Division has been considering the disposition of the school building, we have been asked to define the status of the school lands.

Under date of July 17th, 1911, Joseph Deer, the recognized owner of Lot 503 and Thomas Monique, the recognized owner of Lot 502, transferred to His Majesty by quit claim deeds the portions of the lots required for school purposes, and received compensation for such areas in the amount of $50.00 per acre.

On the question of status of the lands, on being referred to our legal advisers, they have replied that His Majesty the King has no right to hold land on an Indian Reserve for school purposes unless the land was taken for that purpose under Section II of the Indian Act, and as the requisite Order in Council was not secured under Section II in this case, that the transfers made in 1911 were void and the lands transferred would, now that the school has been closed, be available for use by the aforementioned transferors or their heirs.
A rather similar case on the same Reserve involving the Caughnawaga Bush School was recently considered, and a similar opinion given, but in our view, the circumstances were entirely different. In the case of the Bush School, the Indian transferred the property to His Majesty for the sum of $1,000, "for so long as the land was used for school purposes", and we agree that under such circumstances when the land ceased to be used for school purposes, the Indian transferor or his heirs would be entirely free to use the property again.

In the case of the St. Isidore Road School, however, the transfers were not limited for so long as required for school purposes, and the $50.00 per acre paid on the transfer represented the full value of the land so that it appears quite evident that the Indians in question thought they were disposing of all their interest in the lands. While our legal advisers are correct in stating that His Majesty cannot in his own name accept transfers on an Indian Reserve, nevertheless, it is quite clear that the Indians intended to give up all rights to the property and were paid in full for such rights.

We would not be so concerned with this matter were it not for the fact that the Department has in mind selling the school buildings to an Indian for a residence, and if the legal opinion first mentioned is to be accepted, our position would be that the school building actually belongs to the Indian or Indians owning the lands, for the building is of course a fixture. In short, the original transferors or their heirs would now have title to a building worth several thousand dollars, whereas they originally thought they had disposed of all interest in the property.
It is not considered that this would be a desirable situation, and it is therefore recommended that in this instance, we ignore the advice given us by our legal advisers and consider that the transfers made to His Majesty in 1911 be accepted as transfers to the Crown in trust for the Caughnawaga Band. The result of such recommendation would be to permit the Band Council and the Department to work in conjunction as regards a sale of the school building and the land on which it is situated, to some Indian needing a home on the Reserve.

L. Brown,

B. F. Neary, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education

Reference is made to your memorandum of January 31st with reference to the St. Isidore Road, Indian Day School, and your attention is drawn to Mr. Cunningham's opinion of December 22nd, and to my memorandum to file dated January 17th.

There is no question but that the St. Isidore School must be considered as a fixture on the school land comprising parts of Reserve lots 502 and 503, and as such, on the closing of the school, title to the school passes to the owner of the land.

As my memorandum to file sets out, we consider that in the present case, the Caughnawaga Band are the owners of the school land, and that therefore it is within the jurisdiction of the Band Council to decide what disposition should be made of the school and the lands therewith.

We have in mind suggesting to the Band Council that the school either be used as a home for a needy family or families, or in the alternative sold to some Indian, and if our views as to ownership are acceptable to you, I should be very pleased to have you return your file 329-9 in order that the disposition of the school land and school may be taken up with Superintendent Prisebois.

Ottawa, July 14, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant enclosing a sketch and reporting upon the need for a new school-house for the children on the Caughnawaga Indian reserve residing between St. Isidore and Primeau Roads.

In reply I beg to say that it is the intention of the Department to ask Parliament at the next session for an appropriation with which to erect a suitable building for the accommodation of these children and one of the first questions to be taken into consideration is the selection of a suitable site. This should receive consideration by you at an early date. The school should be centrally located and the site should be high and dry and easily drained. Water also should be available and sufficient land to provide the necessary play grounds and also school gardens.

When you have had an opportunity to look into this matter you will be good enough to report.

Your obedient servant,

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Assistant Indian Agent,

St. Constant, August 24th, 1910

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Sir:

Referring to your letter No 158,216/5, dated July 14th, I beg to inform you that I went through the South-West corner of the Caughnawaga reserve, looking for a suitable site for a new school-house between Primeau and St. Isidore roads.

In the same time I have ascertain that there is over fifty children of school age, living into that part of the reserve.

It seems to me that the most suitable site is along the St. Isidore road, where Indians claims winter roads are better.

The best site would be on lot 443, which is high and dry, close to a creek, and sufficient land to provide the necessary play grounds, also school gardens, but I fear this is too much out of center.

Lot 595 is a sugar grove, high and dry and easily drained, but the water is not available, unless an Artesian well could be easily dug up, and I do not believe that we can get any good drinking water in that part of the reserve except from a well.

I do not know yet to whom belong these two lots 595 & 443 but if you authorize me I will find out and let you know how much they are asking for.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst-Agent.

Sir,

Re: St. Isidore Road Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Reserve.

I would refer to your memorandum of January 4, 1949, written in reply to our memorandum of December 6, 1948, re the estate of John Phillips and the Caughnawaga Bush Indian Day School.

In your said memorandum you gave an opinion to the effect that the Quit Claim Deed dated May 8, 1905, between John Phillips and His Majesty, King Edward the Seventh, as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, is void and, therefore, the bush school and the lot on which it is located belonged to John Phillips' Estate. It is my understanding in that particular case, it was said that when John Phillips released the property, he did so for so long as the land was used for school purposes and, therefore, was only paid the sum of $1.00 for the property.

We now have a somewhat similar situation regarding the St. Isidore Road Indian Day School which is located on parts of Reserve Lots 502 and 503. In this case the Indian owners of Lots 502 and 503 released forever their interest in the portions of the lots taken for the school lot and each received compensation at the rate of $50.00 per acre from the land taken from each of their holdings. Quit Claim Deeds were executed on July 17, 1911, between the two owners and His Majesty, King George the Fifth, as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The St. Isidore Road School is no longer used and the Education Division wish to dispose of it to an Indian or Indians. There was never any indication that the original owners of Lots 502 and 508 released the land for the school only for so long as it was used for school purposes as was intimated in the bush road school case. We contend that the owners knowingly released forever their possessory interest in the lands taken for the school lot and now that the lands and buildings are no longer required by the Education Division, they would automatically revert to Band ownership and can be sold or otherwise disposed of by the Band.

I should be very pleased to receive your comments in this matter.

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,

MEMORANDUM TO D. J. ALLAN:

St. Isidore Road Indian Day School,

I acknowledge your memorandum of the 26th ultimo.

Section II of the Indian Act provides that the Governor in Council may take the land of an Indian for school purposes upon payment of compensation agreed upon. If the acquisition of the St. Isidore Indian Day School site was authorized by the Governor in Council, I think that the transaction can be brought within section II of the Act. If, however, there was no such authority for the transaction, in my opinion the transfer is void and the land covered by the transfer is part of the assets of the estate of the transferor. In the latter event, and in view of the fact that the transfer took place on July 17, 1911, it is possible that title to the land is now vested in the band by virtue of section 29 of the Indian Act, and if necessary the facts might be investigated to ascertain if this is so.

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

Re: St. Isidore Road Indian Day School

The above noted school is located on part of Reserve Lots 502 and 508, Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, and as it is no longer required for school purposes, and the Education Division has been considering the disposition of the school building, we have been asked to define the status of the school lands.

Under date of July 17th, 1911, Joseph Deer, the recognized owner of Lot 508 and Thomas Monique, the recognized owner of Lot 502, transferred to His Majesty by quit claim deeds the portions of the lots required for school purposes, and received compensation for such areas in the amount of $50.00 per acre.

On the question of status of the lands, being referred to our legal advisers, they have replied that His Majesty the King has no right to hold land on an Indian Reserve for school purposes unless the land was taken for that purpose under Section II of the Indian Act, and as the requisite Order in Council was not secured under Section II in this case, that the transfers made in 1911 were void and the lands transferred would, now that the school has been closed, be available for use by the aforementioned transferors or their heirs.
A rather similar case on the same Reserve involving the Caughnawaga Bush School was recently considered, and a similar opinion given, but in our view, the circumstances were entirely different. In the case of the Bush School, the Indian transferred the property to His Majesty for the sum of $1.00, "for so long as the land was used for school purposes", and we agree that under such circumstances when the land ceased to be used for school purposes, the Indian transferor or his heirs would be entirely free to use the property again.

In the case of the St. Isidore Road School, however, the transfers were not limited for so long as required for school purposes, and the $50.00 per acre paid on the transfer represented the full value of the land so that it appears quite evident that the Indians in question thought they were disposing of all their interest in the lands. While our legal advisers are correct in stating that His Majesty cannot in his own name accept transfers on an Indian Reserve, nevertheless, it is quite clear that the Indians intended to give up all rights to the property and were paid in full for such rights.

We would not be so concerned with this matter were it not for the fact that the Department has in mind selling the school buildings to an Indian for a residence, and if the legal opinion first mentioned is to be accepted, our position would be that the school building actually belongs to the Indian or Indians owning the lands, for the building is of course a fixture. In short, the original transferors or their heirs would now have title to a building worth several thousand dollars, whereas they originally thought they had disposed of all interest in the property.
It is not considered that this would be a desirable situation, and it is therefore recommended that in this instance, we ignore the advice given us by our legal advisers and consider that the transfers made to His Majesty in 1911 be accepted as transfers to the Crown in trust for the Caughnawaga Band. The result of such recommendation would be to permit the Band Council and the Department to work in conjunction as regards a sale of the school building and the land on which it is situated, to some Indian needing a home on the Reserve.

L. Brown,
Reserves and Trusts.

Dear Sir:

Mr. John Thompson, one of the chiefs of the St. Regis Band, has called on me this morning, and on behalf of the Indians living on St. Regis Island wishes me to protest to you against a movement which has as its object the selling of the schoolhouse on St. Regis Island.
