It is a physical impossibility for these children to attend school at the Indian Village of St. Regis during the fall and spring months, on account of the ice forming in the channel. And during the winter months it is practically impossible for them to attend with any degree of regularity, on account of the distance, and the hardship and danger of winter travelling.

To sell the school-house on St. Regis Island now, simply means that these young children would be absolutely shut out from any
opportunity of acquiring an education, or improving their condition, and would be the direct means of causing them to grow up in the grossest ignorance. I have always understood that the policy of all Governments was to endeavor to educate these people, with the view of making them useful citizens. To sell their school-house, or to permit of its being sold, is not calculated to bring about that result.

Mr. Thompson spoke candidly and emphatically on the subject, and he tells me that the people on St. Regis island, particularly those with children, are most indignant at this proposed attempt to absolutely shut them out from giving their children the education which they so much need.

Mr. Thompson also says that he thinks a competent teacher can be obtained readily on Cornwall Island; one who is familiar with the English and Indian languages.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

I think the Village of St. Regis is a point where some attention should be given to the improvement of its day school facilities. The schools were amalgamated because it was found that the Indians could not afford the large educational expenses which were charged to them and owing to the fact that the interests of the Indians were not being served by such a large number of schools. Deputy Cust. General of Indian Affairs.

I beg to report that, while at St Regis on the 7th instant, I paid a visit to the St Regis island for the purpose of looking into the question of re-opening the school on the island.

The St Regis island is about 3 miles long, with a good road running through the middle or the whole length of it. There are 25 families living thereon, and their farms and houses certainly look far superior to any that I have seen on the reserve, excepting those on Cornwall island. I enclose herewith a snap-shot taken of Michel Francis' house and barns, as a sample, showing the kind of houses that can be seen on this island.

The school is situated just about the middle of the island, on Chief John Thompson's land (see sketch enclosed). The site is beautiful. It stands some 100 yards from the road, in a grove of maple trees, on a high land, overlooking the southern channel of the St Lawrence.

As the school house at present stands in the pasture land, it will be necessary to enclose it with a fence and to provide an independent access from the road to the school, as at present and in former times, the children had to go through private yards to reach it. To meet the needs of the case, Chief Thompson offered to set apart a piece of land 60 paces long and 25 paces wide as the school grounds, surrounding the present site, as well as a road-way immediately in front of the school.
school, across his cleared land, to the main road. If the Department decides to re-open the school, the Chief's offer should be accepted and that he be requested to execute a written conveyance of same.

The school house, which is a frame one, 18x24, was built in the spring of 1835. (See map-shot enclosed.) The outbuildings consist of a store-house, in good condition, and two single closets, both in urgent need of repairs and change of location. To make the school building comfortable and presentable for school purposes, the roof will have to be re-shingled, the walls, both inside and outside, will have to be re-painted, new chimney built and the foundations slightly repaired. The estimated cost of these repairs would not exceed $75.00. I may say that the building has been continuously used by different Indians as a dwelling.

The following school furniture are still on hand;—
14 double desks, a little varnish or paint would improve their appearances; a teacher's desk; a box stove with pipes; and a stock of second-hand school books.

There is no well on the school premises. Drinking water would have to be got from Chief Thompson's well.

The problem of accommodation for the teacher on the island would be a live issue. A native teacher would, of course, have no difficulty to offer in this connection; but a white teacher would certainly have and would either become Indianized and remain content to board with any of the Indians, or have the upper story of the school house fitted for his quarters, or find a more congenial boarding house among the white farmers on the mainland on the Ontario side, the last alternative would be the most satisfactory solution of the situation.

In
In view of the fact that all the Indians on the island are anxious to have the school re-opened, and as there are 36 children under 15 years of age, 23 of whom are of the school age, (see list enclosed) and as none of this number, but three, have attended school for the past 12 years, since 1896, when the school was closed, I beg to recommend that some action be taken immediately to provide facilities whereby the children will be given every opportunity to receive some education. Such condition of affairs, where boys have grown into young manhood without even seeing the inside of a school house, should not be allowed any longer to continue. After the summer holidays, the school should be re-opened, with a competent teacher in charge, and the regulations for compulsory attendance at school should, if found necessary, be put in force and a truant officer appointed to see that the same are complied with. The better element of the island, headed by Chief John Thompson, is decidedly in favour of the application of the compulsory school laws.

The scheme of sending the children to the St. Regis village school is not looked upon with any degree of favour by the parents for the following reasons; the danger and inconvenience in crossing the river in boats, where the channel is fully half a mile wide and the current is both strong and treacherous; the parents have not the time, and some perhaps, have not the inclination to convey their children to and fro twice a day in this manner; the moral atmosphere and influence of the village children, it is stated, is anything but wholesome. The reasonableness of the objection to crossing the river in boats is obvious. No parent, unless unnatural, would allow his child to cross such a river in small boat and feel contented as to the safety of the child.
I beg to suggest that the children be sent, as an experiment for the balance of the present school term, to the village school on Smallman's steamer which plies between Dundee and Cornwall. An arrangement might be made with Mr. Smallman to call at the wharf on St Regis island for the children on his way up in the morning and again on his return trip in the afternoon. According to the time table, the boat calls daily at St Regis at 9 A.M. and 3 P.M., this would give the children ample time at school. Before such an arrangement can be carried out, however, the old wharf on the island would have to be repaired which would, according to the estimate given me by Chief Thompson, cost about $50.00. The need for a serviceable wharf on the island, in any case, is urgent for the use and convenience of the residents. It is situated on Mitchel Francis' farm not far from the present island school house.

A temporary landing might also be built on Yellow island, some point opposite to the St Regis island wharf, for the same steamer to call for the children of that island, who number in all 19 of school age, and transport them to the village, to enable them also to attend school. Although the crossing between Yellow island and the St. Regis village is not so dangerous, excepting on windy days, as compared with the crossing to St Regis island, one of the Indians might be engaged to ferry the children daily to school. The children on this island, in former years, used to attend the Chenail school when it was in operation, but since it was closed, none of them have ever attended any school.

If the scheme of taking the children of the islands to the village school proves popular with the Indians and satisfactory to the Department, a larger school will have to be built, as the present one is not capable of accommodating more
more than 35 pupils. There is now before the Department the question of building a new council house in the village, plans might, therefore, be prepared for a building that would serve the purposes of a council hall and school.

As I was not able to visit the Chenail section of the reserve, I am not in position to offer any report as to the school facilities there. I was told, however, that there were about 40 children that could attend school but have not done so since the Chenail school was closed in 1896. I may say that some of these children live more than five miles from the village and in order to reach it, they would have to cross the St. Regis river.

Chas. A. Clark

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Some of the St. Regis Indians, Chief Thompson among the number, accompanied by William Reep, called at the Department on Friday in regard to the reopening of the school on St. Regis island. They claim that it would be impossible for the children to attend the St. Regis school, as they would have to cross a portion of the St. Lawrence river which is dangerous for children in small boats.

The school was closed some twelve years ago on the supposition that they could attend the village school. Since then they have had no educational advantages and as there are about twenty-five children of school age it is a pity that they should be allowed to grow up in ignorance. They have a building on the island which could be put in fair repair for about $55 and Chief Thompson offered to do the necessary work for this amount.

Mr. Reep has applied for the position of teacher and as none of the children have attended any school he would be able to give the necessary instruction, should the Department have sufficient reliance in his steadiness to appoint him. He would be willing to take his dismissal at any time if he failed to give satisfaction. It would be
a difficult to obtain a white teacher to live on the island, where he or she would be obliged to reside. One with some knowledge of the Indian language would be better adapted to the work.

It is for the Department to say whether the school will be reopened, the necessary repairs made and Mr. Roep given a chance or the services of someone else obtained.

When I was engaged to take charge of this school, I had in mind of boarding with a relative who lives near by but I was very much disappointed later on to find...
the place not suitable, but I stayed on all last fall, part of the winter and a few weeks during spring.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Last November Miss McGoey, the teacher of the St. Regis Island Indian School, applied for an increase in salary. She is now paid at the rate of $450.00 per annum and has been in the service of the Department since the 14th of March, 1912, having formerly taught for three years on the Mississauga Reserve.

Mr. Agent Taillon was asked for a report on Miss McGoey's application and he has replied stating that "during the short time she has been with us her services have been very satisfactory; she seems to have a very keen interest in her work and the children under her care. The Indians generally and more especially on St. Regis Island seem to hold her in very high esteem. Judging from the work already performed, I consider her a capable and very efficient teacher and have no hesitation in recommending an increase, as I think good teachers among the Indians need and should be encouraged".

Miss McGoey called hereon her way back to St. Regis.
Regis Island after the Christmas holidays and told me that, while she is interested in her work, she finds the conditions on the Island harder than she expected, as she is almost entirely cut off from association with whites, it being a difficult matter to get off the Island and when she does so she has to pay the Indians every time they take her across, even when she is going to church. The boarding accommodation is very primitive and she has to spend a good deal for necessaries in the shape of food that the Indians do not furnish.

I think the Department would be quite justified in increasing her salary to $500.00 a year.

Mr. Public School Inspector Gilman, who visited the St. Regis Island school, shortly after Miss McGoey took charge, reports that she is successful in her work.

On Saturday, the 29th ultimo, I visited the St. Regis reserve, for the purpose of meeting the teachers and trying to straighten out several little difficulties in connection with the professional services. I explained to them that any teacher who could not work and live in harmony with the others on the reserve had a disturbing influence which would interfere with success in the classrooms. Miss E. Prudhomme, of Chetlain, handed in her resignation to take effect as soon as she could be relieved. I definitely placed Miss Macduffy in charge of the girls, both as far as their classroom activity was concerned and in their residence. I laid down the rule that the village residence was to be used by the Chetlain and Chenail teachers from Saturday until Sunday only and that they upon those occasions were to meet a fair share of the cost and to assist in the work. I arranged for the installation of Miss Carmel Dunnigen, the new teacher at St. Regis Island, who is to live with the two village teachers in the village residence. Mr. MacGibbon, the new Indian agent, is quite sincere and eager to do his best and I believe in time will be a good representative.

My dear Sir,

It gratifies us to know that our girl graduates receive sufficient training in our schools to be recommended as teachers. Miss Snow of the class '24 who has replaced some teachers now and then in case of sickness, is a well qualified little person and teacher; but her mother will not allow her to leave home. She is very timid and frail.

As a mark of appreciation for your great kindness and your constant cooperation in our work, I would sacrifice Miss Snow our best assistant teacher. She has been associated with the work of the primary classes and has always given entire satisfaction for four years. She is twenty-five years old, painstaking, trustful and very respectable.

She was trained by one of our most competent teachers, consequently she was moulded into a capable, conscientious teacher. Her love for children, together with the many plans and devices taught her have assured her success. She commands respect from the children, she has discipline and assumes control. Apparently she is quiet and seems to enjoy my place she calls her home. I think she is just the sort of a girl you need in that lonely village of St. Regis.

If you intend to secure her services, I would advise you to do so soon before she goes away for the summer. Also state the salary as money plays a very important role with the Iroquois.

Trusting I have given you sufficient information, I am,

Dear Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

Sister Mary Rose Alm
Principal

Madam:

Pursuant to our conversation yesterday, I wish to confirm your appointment as teacher of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, at a salary of $70 per teaching month. The island is in the St. Lawrence river, a few miles east of Cornwall. The teacher will live at St. Regis Village, which is on the south shore, with three other teachers of Indian schools.

Duties will commence on September 2nd. The best way to reach the school is by train to Ryando Junction, New York, and then take a bus or car to St. Regis Village. Miss Margaret MacNulty, of R.R. No. 1, Achmad, Ont., is the principal of the Village School and is in charge of the teachers' residence. You will have to be taken across to the Island by boat, morning and night. The residence is heated and furnished, but you will have to share the cost of meals, etc., with the other teachers. Mr. W. A. MacGibbon is the Indian agent at St. Regis. He has the same relation to you as school trustees and you should look to him for guidance in all matters pertaining to the conduct of your school and your relations with the Indians. Miss MacNulty will no doubt give you advice in connection with teaching methods.

I may say that Miss Helena Dubois, of Hammond's Bridge, Telephone R-2098 J., has recently been appointed teacher at St. Regis Village. She has been in touch with Miss MacNulty, the principal, and is informed regarding conditions. You might be well advised to telephone to Miss Dubois and arrange to travel with her to your new duties. Mr. Indian Agent MacGibbon has been informed of your appointment.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,

Madam:

Pursuant to your conversation with Mr. Ferrier, I have to confirm your appointment as teacher of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, near Cornwall, Ont., duties to commence on September first, next. Salary at the rate of $80 per teaching month will be allowed in your case. This salary will be subject to a 10% deduction during the present fiscal year.

This school is situated on St. Regis Island in the St. Lawrence river. It is a mile and a half from St. Regis Village, which is in Quebec. You will reside in St. Regis Village. Miss Frances Morris, of Sheenboro, Que., is the senior teacher on the reserve, and, in connection with academic questions, you should look to her for advice as you commence your work. The Indian Agent, who would bear the same relation to you as a local School Board, is Mr. W. A. MacGibbon. He lives at St. Regis and you should look to him for instructions and advice in all general matters. The best way to proceed to your school by train is by New York Central to Nyando Junction, N.Y., and then get a car to St. Regis Village. However, I would advise you to drive to the school when you first go there, using the ferry which is just to the east of Cornwall. Take a ferry which goes to St. Regis Village. The wharf is but a couple of hundred yards from your residence.

During the winter months, you would ski or snowshoe to your school, approximately 1½ miles. In the summer, the Department engages an Indian to row you across to the island, night and morning.

If anything interferes with your accepting this post, please write to the Department without delay.

Quarterly Report
St. Regis Indian Agency

Schools:

Below is the percentage of attendance of our schools during the quarter under review:

| School                  | December | November | October |
|-------------------------|----------|----------|---------|
| Cornwall Ild. E. School | 59.7     | 61.6     | 77.8    |
| Cornwall Ild. W. "      | 61       | 68       | 68      |
| Village School - Senior | 71.6     | 88.1     | 87.8    |
| " - Junior              | 67.3     | 94.2     | 91      |
| Chenail School          | 80       | 94       | 90.9    |
| Chetlain                | 93       | 94.2     | 92      |
| St. Regis Island        | 76.6     | 67.5     | 77.09   |

It will be noted in some cases very low average for December. This is due to the flu epidemic mostly. In general it can be said that attendance at the various schools has maintained a high level. Such a high percentage is particularly noteworthy at the Chetlain school where it was difficult to get the boys to school. The reverse is now the case as far as the boys are concerned. With the exception of the Cornwall Island east school no manual training is carried on. The village boys get the benefit of some training along this line when such is possible with the time at the disposal of the local constable. With only one man now working here less time can be devoted to such work amongst the boys. Due to the poor facilities at St. Lawrence this winter it has not been possible during December to get to St. Regis Island School. The conditions are such that it is not safe to walk nor can a boat be used. Only emergency trips are made by the Indian residents of the island.

In general the children on the whole appear to be well-behaved and industrious. There is very little incentive for those children in our Quebec schools to develop much energy to studies after they reach the age of 15 as the prospect of being able to attend a high school is no better than in past years. The hardest period to keep those children at school is between the age of 15 and 16. The boys in particular just wont exert themselves too much after 15. This situation is most unfortunate as they have just reached a point in life when they should be capable of absorbing some knowledge. I feel though that if we could give them the kind of training they would like at this period we would be well repaid and would not have any attendance problem on our hands to contend with.

T.L. Bonnah,
Indian Agent.

Dear Madam:

Mr. T. L. Bonnah, your Indian Agent, has forwarded to me the attendance percentages of the schools in his agency for the month of April.

May I add my congratulations to him for this splendid achievement of your pupils and yourself.

It is only by continual attendance that our Indian children can achieve results similar to those of the white children. If we wish them to advance to higher education, it is most important that they have a thorough and complete grounding in their elementary studies. This can only be obtained by diligent work and constant attendance.

I will watch with interest the progress of the children at your school and it is my sincere hope that your pupils will proceed to high schools, technical schools and other institutions of advanced learning.

Sincerely yours,

Ottawa, August 22nd, 1924.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, in which you inform the Department that you prefer teaching at the St. Regis Island Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that your appointment as teacher of this school, at a salary of $500 per year, plus bonus is approved. Payment of salary and bonus is based on the ten teaching months in the school year. The Department expects this school to be re-opened on September 2nd, next. You will have to come via Ottawa, and when you reach here you should visit the Schools Branch of this Department, which is situated in Room 501 of the Booth Building, Sparks St. Information will then be furnished you regarding your trip from Ottawa to the St. Regis Reserve.

In connection with the Sagamook School, I would inform you that other arrangements are being made regarding the securing of a teacher and there will therefore be no vacancy for your brother.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Kathleen R. Murphy,
Demers Centre, R.R. No. 2,
Que.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, enclosing a doctor's certificate regarding your illness.

In reply I beg to say that the Department regrets to learn of your illness and hopes that you will have sufficiently recovered to resume duties as teacher of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School at an early date.

When you prepare your return for the current quarter you should state in a note thereon the dates between which the school was closed on account of your illness. If you are not absent from duties for more than two weeks, the time stated by the doctor as being necessary, the Department will allow you salary for the period the school was closed. We hope, however, that you will be able to re-open school at an early date.

Ottawa, November 20th, 1945.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector who recently visited the St. Regis Island Indian Day School recommends that the salary of the teacher, Miss Kathleen Murphy, be increased. He states that the hazardous trip made by her twice a day in an open boat, the long walk to and from her school, require special consideration from the Department.

In view of the circumstances mentioned by the Inspector and also on account of the services which Miss Murphy performs, the department will approve of an increase of $5 per teaching month in her salary from the 1st of January, next. This will make her salary from that date at the rate of $70 per teaching month. I shall be pleased if you will inform her of the increase in salary granted.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mclean,

St. Regis, Jan.

Dear Mr. Grier:

Would it be alright if Miss Stafford closed school on Thursday of this week until after some holidays?

She has three sloughed fields to cross and a very cold trip on the water which leaves her so exhausted that she has to go to bed when she gets in each evening. She would need nothing in time rather than continual under sweat conditions. As I am responsible for her being here I am rather worried over her condition at present. I will be expecting a letter from you by Wednesday advising what should be done.

I am informed by Mr. Leary that it is expected we return for Jan 4th. That is not usual. Mr. Grier in separate schools,

Ottawa, August 5, 1908.

The Acting Deputy Minister,

The St. Regis Island school is centrally situated and with the following repairs will answer for a long time. It is 16'9" by 24'6" and 11' high and well lighted. There are ten pine desks, which, if fastened to the floor, would provide the necessary accommodation, if three more were added. The inside plastering along the floor should be protected by a rainsealing and the outside would be better for painting.

Mr. Thompson, on whose farm the school-house is located, has offered to do the whole of the work for $33.00, and I would recommend that Mr. Agent Long be authorized to have the repairs made by him, as he takes a great interest in the school and keeps it in good order. I found the closets clean and about one and one-half tons of coal on hand. This school was closed for some years and I consider the Department was quite justified in reopening it, as the children on the island could not possibly attend the St. Regis school, owing to the distance and having to cross a wide arm of the St. Lawrence.

The late teacher, who was too young and inexperienced for the work, has resigned and a new one is needed. An application has been received from Joseph F. Phillips for the position of teacher at The Chenaill. He is
apparently a well-educated Indian, who completed his course in the St. Laurent College, near Montreal, and has enclosed his diploma. I think an Indian teacher better suited for this school than a white for the present, as the pupils are all in the lower standards and very few of them understand English. It is an isolated place for a white teacher, but an Indian would adapt himself to his surroundings and comfortable board and lodging could be secured at Mr. Thompson's at a very reasonable rate. I would suggest that he be offered the position, as I know he would be suitable to the Indians.

Ottawa, October 5, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st instant in reference to the equipment of the St. Basil Island School.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the good attendance, the Department is prepared to place new desks in this school and 16 double desks of suitable sizes will be ordered from the James Smart Manufacturing Co., Brockville, to be shipped to Cornwall addressed to you. The firm will be asked to advise you by mail when the desks are shipped and you will be good enough then to make the necessary arrangements to have them taken to the Island and placed in position. The Department will remunerate you for this work.

In reference to the blackboards, you will be good enough to state exactly the sizes of the boards needed to fill in the space between between the chimney and the wall in the front of the school-room. When this information is received hyloplate boards will be ordered from Toronto.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. John Thompson,
St. Basil, Que.,
Secretary.

Are thoroughly well known throughout the entire Dominion, being in use in hundreds of schools, and are universally recognized as the strongest, most substantial, most attractive, least expensive and most satisfactory generally of all the desks in the market.

DEAR SIR:

The writer made a personal inspection of the schoolhouse on St. Regis Island and found same in a very poor condition for school children. The ceiling at present is only 7 ft. 10 in. high and the lumber forming same of a very rough quality with cracks and knot holes and only one thickness at that. The wainscoting is 2 ft. 6 in. high and above that to ceiling is plaster; this is all picked and broken and could not be repaired by patching. The door is a 1" batton door and the frame very bad and roughly put in—both door and frame are required new. The windows are in good shape (we made same a short time ago for an indian, we think).

We would suggest that the ceiling and walls above present ceiling be done as follows in order to make building warm and comfortable. Carry walls up say 2 ft. 6 in. higher than present wall from ceiling to have about 2 ft. 6 in. of segment in centre of building thus leaving ceiling from floor level at centre of building about 12 ft. The ceiling and side walls should have two boardings of matched boards, 2 layers felt, and should be ceiled on face side say with 5/8" V. joint and carried down to wainscoting. Finish doors and windows to receive the ceiling. The floor or base of floor re-
quires a moulding around as the base was not put on very closely. The chimney stands at present on two plank—this also would require to be finished around. The seats are all in good shape. The teacher's desk is a common box on four legs.

We will do all above mentioned work, furnishing all material and painting interior with two coats (color to suit) for the sum of two hundred and ten dollars ($210.00). Should you think a teacher's desk necessary we will put one in for seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) extra. If favored with this work we wish you would kindly give us order as soon as possible as it is very difficult to get material on the Island. We are

Yours very truly

Dict. L. A. R.

O.

Ottawa, February 28, 1912.

Gentlemen,

The Department regrets to have to call your attention to the fact that the lumber supplied by you last summer for repairs to the school on St. Regis Island was not up to the standard. It was not properly seasoned and the Public School Inspector reports that as a result the joints are parted to the extent of from one-half to one inch in some places.

I may also say that a similar complaint in regard to the interior woodwork in the new school in the village of St. Regis has been received.

The Department has no doubt that you were not aware of the fact that the lumber furnished was not properly seasoned and therefore request that you will be willing to make the necessary reparation. I shall be glad to hear from you in regard to these matters.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Messrs. Ross & Co.,
Cornwall, Ont.

DEAR SIR:

Your favor of the 28th. ult. #151936/5 re schoolhouses at St. Regis Island and St. Regis to hand.

Re school-house on the Island we made enquiries from our man who did the work and he seemed greatly surprised at the complaint, however he told us that the Indian who carried the lumber across the River when unloading one of the loads let a portion of the material fall off into the water but it was not in it very long.

Re shrinkage of finish at St. Regis village schoolhouse--we can partly account for this as the building was left last fall without being heated up during a very damp spell and when we went over later to make some necessary changes on ventilators and repairs to windows we found that the finish was bulged out considerably (this your architect will endorse). We repaired
MR. J. D. MCLEAN

same at the time knowing that when dried out the lumber would shrink.

We will examine again both of these buildings and make all necessary repairs. We must say that we do not send out lumber from our factory for interior work without first thoroughly kiln drying same—either for custom or our own use.
